title: JPMorgan shares leap after bank raises interest income target
text:
JPMorgan Chase shares enjoyed their best day in more than a year on Monday as the largest US bank by assets signalled that it would earn billions of dollars more than previously expected from its lending business.

The updated outlook was delivered during an investor day at its Manhattan headquarters, held in response to shareholder concerns about the Wall Street bank's strategic direction and spending plans.

JPMorgan raised the outlook for how much its core lending business will earn this year to more than $56bn, from at least $53bn previously, as it anticipates benefits from rising interest rates. By the fourth quarter of 2022, net interest income on annualised basis will be at least $66bn, the bank anticipated.

Shares of JPMorgan closed 6.2 per cent higher on the news, outpacing the broader KBW Bank index and marking the stock's biggest one-day gain since November 2020.

“We have a very compelling story. You saw that sizzle reel,” chief executive Jamie Dimon told investors, referring to a promotional video played at the start of the event.

“I would buy that stock,” he joked.

Analysts had expected the lender would lift its NII guidance — the difference between what banks pay on deposits and what they earn from loans and other assets — after the Federal Reserve indicated it would lift rates faster than previously expected to combat high inflation.

Given the brighter NII outlook, Dimon said there was a “very good chance” the bank would hit a medium-term target for return on tangible common equity, a crucial measure of profitability, of roughly 17 per cent in 2022 and that it may exceed that target in 2023 “in a benign environment”. The bank had guided in January that it could miss the target this year and next.

Higher rates should enable lenders such as JPMorgan to earn more from the loans they make.

However, some analysts have expressed concerns that aggressive monetary tightening risks pushing the US economy into a recession, an environment in which banks often struggle.

Despite the upbeat guidance and what it said was a “strong” US economy, the bank warned investors of the “storm clouds” of high inflation and the war in Ukraine.

JPMorgan president Daniel Pinto also cautioned that fees from investment banking would be down about 45 per cent year on year in the second quarter as part of a slowdown in dealmaking. Revenues from trading, however, would pick up some of the slack and should be up 10-15 per cent, Pinto said.

Dimon and about a dozen of his top lieutenants spent much of the five-hour investor event providing more details of the benefits the bank expects to gain from around $15bn in new investments budgeted for 2022.

The spending was announced in January and spooked investors. The plans include $6.7bn on technology investments, which far exceed what rival banks have earmarked.

“I want to get the modernisation [of the bank's technology] done,” Dimon said. “It's a lot of work.”

Additional reporting by Eric Platt in New York
